It is unlikely that solar energy alone will completely replace all other forms of energy, at least not in the short term. While solar energy is becoming increasingly popular and cost-effective, it currently makes up only a small portion of the total energy mix globally. Moreover, there are some challenges associated with solar energy, such as intermittency (since the sun doesn't always shine), the need for large land areas for solar panel installations, and the production of hazardous waste during the manufacturing process. 

In the long term, however, it is possible that a combination of renewable energy sources, including solar, wind, hydro, and others, could play a much larger role in the global energy mix, eventually replacing all fossil fuel-based energy sources. To achieve this, significant investments in research, development, and infrastructure will be required. That being said, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to the global energy challenge, and different regions may rely on different energy sources depending on factors such as available resources, climate, and demographics.
